bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert C. Gooch, February 24, 1941

div1.p: Hench thanks Gooch for a copy of published reports by the Military Governor of Cuba for the years 1899 to 1901. He requests similar reports for the years 1898 and 1902. Hench is also looking for official documents referring to the "Cuban War" and the American intervention thereafter.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert C. Gooch, February 24, 1941
div1.opener:
February 24, 1941
Reference to your letter of
Feb. 18, 1941 1b 2031
Mr. Robert C. Gooch
Chief of the Book Services
Reading Rooms
Library of Congress
Washington, D. C.
My dear Mr. Gooch:
div1.p:
I appreciate greatly the receipt of catalog cards concerning the
published reports of the Military Governor of Cuba for the years 1899 to 1901.
Would you kindly send me similar cards for the years 1890 and 1902 (and any other
years in which they appeared).

I have examined these cards carefully and see that I will find much useful
information therein; I plan to borrow several of them through interlibrary loan via
the Mayo Clinic Library. But I am somewhat confused. I note that all the cards you
sent me referred to civil reports and I do not find listed therein certain reports I
am most anxious to consult and which were listed in the New York Public Library under
the following headings:
(1) U. S. Adjutant General's office, Havana Dept, - Annual Report of the
Commanding General 1898.
(2) Same for 1899
(3) Same for 1900
(4) Same for 1901
(5) Same for 1902
(6) Report of Brigadier General William Ludlow, U.S. Army, Military
Governor of Habana, 1899-1900.

I am most anxious to get a list of all official documents referring to the
Cuban War and to the American Intervention thereafter (1898-1902). If you have them
will you please send me reference cards to the six reports listed above and to others
which you might have. Perhaps you have cards referring to the annual Reports of the
War Department for the years 1898-1902.

The possession of these official reference cards would permit me to order
more intelligently, through interlibrary loan, such books as I may need. I should
be glad to pay whatever expense is involved in getting these cards.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
